author: Mina Chong
title: genrec termination argument
question:
Hi, here's my solution for problem 5 from @689 :
(@htdf sel-sort)
(@signature (listof Natural) -> (listof Natural))
;; produce list of given numbers sorted from smallest to largest
;; CONSTRAINT: no number in the list is 0
(check-expect (sel-sort empty) empty)
(check-expect (sel-sort (list 1 2 3)) (list 1 2 3))
(check-expect (sel-sort (list 1 3 2)) (list 1 2 3))
(check-expect (sel-sort (list 2 1 3)) (list 1 2 3))
(check-expect (sel-sort (list 2 3 1)) (list 1 2 3))
(check-expect (sel-sort (list 3 2 1)) (list 1 2 3))
(check-expect (sel-sort (list 3 1 2)) (list 1 2 3))

;(define (sel-sort lon) lon) ;stub

(@template genrec)
#|
Three part termination argument.

Base case: (empty? lon)

Reduction step: (remove (smallest lon) lon)

Termination argument: Each iteration removes one element from lon,
so eventually it will reach the base case, where the lon is empty.

|#

(define (sel-sort lon)
  (if (<= 0 (length lon) 1)
      lon
      (local [(define (smallest lon)
                (cond [(empty? (rest lon)) (first lon)]
                      [else
                       (if (< (first lon) (smallest (rest lon)))
                           (first lon)
                           (smallest (rest lon)))]))]
        (cons (smallest lon)
              (sel-sort (remove (smallest lon) lon))))))
I was hoping for some feedback if this is fulfilling the problem description of selective sorting, that is:
Given a list of numbers lon:

 - If the list has length 0 or 1 it is sorted.

 - Otherwise, find the smallest number in the list, remove it from where
   it appears, bring it to the front, and recursively sort the remaining list.
Also, is the 3 part termination argument provided sufficient? Thanks!
